name: Adaptive Cognitive Gaming Experience
description: This use case enables older adults with diverse preferences and privacy concerns to engage in personalized cognitive stimulation games that adapt to their motivation levels and avoid challenging exercises, promoting mental health while respecting their communication and data-sharing preferences.
scenario:
Olivia, a retired social worker who lives alone in the suburbs, wakes up feeling a bit grumpy as usual. She’s skeptical about using ALFRED’s cognitive games; the idea of technology monitoring her recovery feels intrusive, and she’s particularly concerned about privacy. When ALFRED suggests a memory challenge game tailored to her interests, Olivia dismisses the notification immediately—she has blocked most notifications, especially anything remotely challenging. She prefers to initiate interactions herself, so she activates ALFRED’s voice assistant only when she feels like it, speaking firmly and expecting concise responses without unnecessary explanations. Olivia also insists that all communications remain formal, even with her family, and blocks any data sharing with caregivers or third parties, making ALFRED’s usual data-sharing features useless in her case.

Meanwhile, Elena, who lives in the city and is much more tech-curious, eagerly accepts ALFRED’s game suggestions. She enjoys pushing herself with more demanding exercises and appreciates ALFRED’s proactive notifications and reminders, even when they interrupt her day. Elena often engages in social games that connect her with friends and family, relishing the spontaneous, informal chats and video check-ins that ALFRED facilitates without hesitation. She embraces wearables and health sensors, allowing ALFRED to track her progress continuously, which motivates her to stay active and mentally sharp.

The tension between Olivia’s cautious, controlled approach and Elena’s open, enthusiastic engagement highlights the system’s challenge in catering to such divergent preferences. Olivia’s refusal to share data or accept unsolicited prompts means ALFRED must remain almost invisible in her daily routine, serving only when explicitly requested, while Elena experiences a fully integrated, dynamic cognitive stimulation experience. Despite sharing the same platform, their interactions with ALFRED couldn’t be more different—Olivia uses it as a strictly utilitarian tool to maintain control, whereas Elena embraces it as an active partner in her health and social life. This contrast underscores how ALFRED must adapt not just its games but the entire communication style and data handling to honor each user’s personal boundaries and motivations.
